Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the Southwest Local Algebra Meeting 2020, held at Tulane University on March 7 â€“ March 8, 2020. This conference will facilitate interactions between students and faculty from institutions in the Southwest who have interests in ring theory. The study of rings, in the broadest sense, is crucial to many branches of mathematics, including commutative and non-commutative geometry, group representations, number theory, coding theory, and cryptography. Algebraists in the Southwest region pursue research on a variety of topics under the umbrella of pure and applied ring theory. The meeting will bring together students and faculty from a variety of institutions for inspiring talks, with ample time for scientific interaction, providing opportunities for participants to begin new collaborations and catalyzing new research projects. About 70 participants are expected, including students and young and senior faculty from throughout the South and Southwestern USA. The participation of students from underrepresented minority groups, women, untenured faculty, and faculty at non-Ph.D. granting institutions is particularly encouraged. Six experts will deliver hour-long talks on topics within their areas of specialty. The lectures are intended to be accessible to graduate students. The meeting will also feature three hour-long poster sessions in which the participating students will present their research.

Participants will discuss several key problems in commutative algebra, including progress on finding bounds for Betti numbers, a topic that has significant implications for classical problems in combinatorics and algebraic geometry, including Cayley-Bacharach theory. Several speakers work in combinatorial or computational algebraic geometry and will also shed light on connections between these fields and commutative algebra. Finally, the research expertise of one speaker is in Representation Theory, providing an opportunity to introduce ring theorists to problems in a different field close to their areas of work. More information can be found at the conference webpage: http://www.math.ttu.edu/~lchriste/slam2020.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary of Outcomes: The Southwest Local Algebra Meeting 2020 took place at Tulane University, in New Orleans, LA on March 7-8, 2020. This was the 11th annual Southwest Local Algebra Meeting. The first meeting was held at the University of Texas-Arlington in 2010 and, since then, has been rotating around various universities in the region. The purpose of the meeting was to facilitate interactions between young and seninor mathematicians, with interests in ring theory, broadly interpreted, from universities and institutions in the Southwest and South areas.

For the 2020 meeting, participants met at Tulane University for talks, graduate student poster sessions, and mathematical discussions. The six speakers were Mahir Can (Tulane University), Luis Garcia Puente (Sam Houston University), Mohsen Gheibi (University of Texas at Arlington), Srikanth Iyengar (University of Utah), Claudia Polini (University of Notre Dame) and Sandra Spiroff (University of Mississippi), who talked about currently active research topics in the areas of Representation Theory, Algebraic Statistics, Homological Algebra, Derived Category and Commutative Algebra. All the talks were accessible to graduate students and often illustrating connections between basic materials learned in graduate school with latest advances in their research fields.

Thirteen graduate students from six different universities presented posters during three 50-minute poster sessions, explaining their research to other students and faculty. The posters were from Rebekah Aduddel, Tyler Anway, and Hung Tran of the University of Texas at Arlington; from Tekin Karadag, Tolulope Oke, Pablo Sanchez Ocal and Alexandra Sobieska of Texas A&M University; from Sankhaneel Bisui, Tien Le and Abu Thomas of Tulane University; from Pinches Dirnfeld of the University of Utah; from Zachary Flores of Colorado State University; and from Jesse Keyton of the University of Arkansas. 

The total attendance of the meeting was 55. Participants came from across the Southwest and South regions, including Louisiana, Texas, New Mexico, Mississippi, Arkansas, and a few additional states including Utah, Corolado, Indianna. The participants include students from underrepresented groups, women, and faculty at all career stages, and from different types of institutions. Most of the NSF support was used for hotel accommodation and travel for students and faculty with limited access to fundings.

Intellectual Merit: The study of rings, in the broadest sense, is at the intersection of many branches of mathematics, including commutative algebra, non-commutative geometry, representation theory, number theory, coding theory and cryptography, and touches on even more, such as combinatorics, homotopy theory and statistics. Algebraists in the Southwest and South regions pursue research on a variety of topics under the umbrella of pure and applied ring theory. Due to the vast physical extension between universities in the Southwest and South regions, professional interactions between experts and graduate students in these regions are challenging. The meeting achieved the goal of bringing together students, post-doctoral researchers and faculty from a variety of institutions for inspired talks, together with ample time for scientific interaction and professional networking. At the meeting, several faculty working on related research problems using different languages and approaches began fruitful conversations about common research interest and possible combination of their methods -- we expect these interactions to lead to more successful research collaboration.

Broader Impacts: The Southwest and South regions are home to many non-PhD granting institutions. Faculty at these institutions have relative access to travel funds which limits their abilities of attending conferences where cutting-edge research is discussed. The relative proximity of the meeting venue and the availability of participation supports offered them an opportunity to connect or reconnect with research groups in their geographical areas. For several graduate students this was one of the very first scientific meeting that they attended. It provided these students a smooth introduction to professional circles. The ample time dedicated to graduate student poster sessions helped the presenters -- and the young graduate students -- interact more comfortably with faculty from other institutions. For instance, an outcome of these interactions was that some students were invited to give their first talk at departmental seminars or other professional meetings. Moreover, many graduate students from non-PhD granting institutions spoke with current faculty at doctoral-granting institutions to discuss their possibilities in pursuing PhD studies in the regions. We anticipate that these connection will help students in their future academic pursuits.
